rsbNotes.title: Luke 16:19
rsbNotes.text:
16:19 a rich man. This man is sometimes called “Dives,” from the Latin word meaning “rich.”

purple and fine linen. The expensive clothing of the rich. Purple would be used for the outer garment and linen for the undergarment.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 16:20
rsbNotes.text: 16:20 Lazarus. The only character given a name in Jesus’ parables.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 16:22
rsbNotes.text:
16:22 Jesus says nothing about the religious condition of either, but it is implied that Lazarus was right with God whereas the rich man was not.

Abraham’s side. The image of “side” relates to being the guest of honor at a banquet (see John 13:23).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 16:23
rsbNotes.text: 16:23 in Hades. The usual Greek name for the place of the dead. In the New Testament it is not used with reference to the righteous. Here it is clearly a place of torment. See “Hell” at Mark 9:43.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 16:24
rsbNotes.text: 16:24 Even in Hades the rich man is arrogant, thinking that he can have Lazarus sent to do his bidding.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 16:25
rsbNotes.text:
16:25 The address “Child” is tender, but it cannot alter the facts. A great chasm separates them, and there is a whole new order with a complete reversal of earthly values.

your good things. The rich man had received what he saw as good things. He could have chosen the things of God, but he preferred physical pleasures.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 16:27–28
rsbNotes.text: 16:27, 28 For the first time the rich man thinks of someone else, though he still remains within his own family. And he still assumes that Lazarus may be sent to do his bidding.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 16:29
rsbNotes.text: 16:29 Moses and the Prophets. A reference to the Old Testament as a whole. The rich man assumed that the appearance of Lazarus would be effective. Jesus is saying that they have the witness of the Word of God; having rejected it, they will not accept another.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 17:1
rsbNotes.text: 17:1 Temptations to sin. The Greek word originally designated the bait stick of a trap; it came to mean anything that trips people up and traps them (see text note).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 17:2
rsbNotes.text: 17:2 little ones. Children or humble believers (cf. 10:21), who are helpless apart from God’s aid.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 17:5–6
rsbNotes.text: 17:5, 6 Apparently the apostles thought great faith would be needed to be so forgiving. Jesus points to what even small faith can bring about. More important than the quantity of faith is the object of faith—a great and powerful God.
